canonical_explanation.text: Electrolysis is the decomposition of an ionic compound by passing electric current through it in molten or aqueous state. Electrolytes are substances that conduct electricity when molten or dissolved; strong electrolytes ionize completely, weak electrolytes ionize partially. During electrolysis, cations migrate to the cathode (negative electrode) where reduction occurs, and anions migrate to the anode (positive electrode) where oxidation occurs. Key electrolyses include: molten PbBr2 produces Pb at cathode and Br2 at anode; acidified water produces H2 at cathode and O2 at anode in 2:1 ratio; CuSO4 with copper electrodes results in copper transfer from anode to cathode.
rules: Electrolyte: conducts electricity in molten/aqueous state
Strong electrolytes: completely ionized (NaCl, HCl, NaOH)
Cathode: negative electrode, site of reduction
Anode: positive electrode, site of oxidation
Cations migrate to cathode, anions migrate to anode
Electrolysis of acidified water: H2:O2 = 2:1 by volume
Electrorefining: purification of metals using electrolysis

questions.question_text: An electrolyte is a substance that:

options.text: Conducts electricity when molten or dissolved in water
Conducts electricity only in gaseous state

questions.explanation_correct: An electrolyte is a substance that conducts electricity when it is molten (in liquid form) or dissolved in water. This is because an electrolyte contains ions that can freely move and carry electric current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because electrolytes do not conduct electricity in the solid state. Option C is incorrect because electrolytes do conduct electricity. Option D is incorrect because electrolytes conduct electricity in both molten and aqueous (dissolved in water) states, not just in the gaseous state.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a strong electrolyte?
questions.explanation_correct: Sodium chloride (NaCl) is a strong electrolyte because it completely dissociates into sodium (Na+) and chloride (Cl-) ions when dissolved in water, allowing it to conduct electricity well.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acetic acid (CH3COOH) is a weak electrolyte, meaning it only partially dissociates into ions when dissolved in water. Ammonia solution (NH3) and alcohol (C2H5OH) are not electrolytes at all, as they do not have ions that can conduct electricity. Therefore, the correct strong electrolyte option is sodium chloride (NaCl).

questions.question_text: A non-electrolyte is:
questions.explanation_correct: Sugar solution is a non-electrolyte because sugar (sucrose) does not ionize or dissociate into ions when dissolved in water. Non-electrolytes do not conduct electricity as they lack mobile charged particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options (A, B, D) are all electrolytes. Sodium chloride (A) and potassium hydroxide (D) are strong electrolytes that ionize completely in water. Hydrochloric acid (B) is a weak electrolyte that ionizes partially in water. These electrolytes can conduct electricity due to the presence of mobile charged ions.

questions.question_text: The cathode in an electrolytic cell is:
questions.explanation_correct: The cathode is the negatively charged electrode in an electrolytic cell. This is because during electrolysis, positively charged cations migrate towards the cathode and undergo reduction (gain electrons) to form neutral atoms or molecules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cathode is not positively charged, neutral, or variable in charge. It is specifically the negatively charged electrode where reduction takes place. This is because positive ions (cations) are attracted to and deposit at the negatively charged cathode during electrolysis.

questions.question_text: During electrolysis, cations migrate towards the:
questions.explanation_correct: During electrolysis, cations (positively charged ions) migrate towards the cathode (negative electrode) because they are attracted to the negative charge of the cathode.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that cations migrate towards the cathode during electrolysis. This is because cations are positively charged and are attracted to the negative electrode (cathode), where reduction occurs. The anions (negatively charged ions) migrate towards the anode (positive electrode), where oxidation occurs.

questions.question_text: Oxidation takes place at the:
questions.explanation_correct: Oxidation takes place at the anode (positive electrode) during electrolysis. This is because the anions (negatively charged ions) migrate to the anode, where they are oxidized (lose electrons) to form neutral atoms or molecules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cathode (negative electrode) is where reduction occurs, where cations (positively charged ions) gain electrons and are reduced. Oxidation always takes place at the anode during electrolysis, as the anions move there and lose electrons.

questions.question_text: During electrolysis of molten lead bromide, at the cathode:
questions.explanation_correct: During the electrolysis of molten lead bromide, lead ions (Pb2+) at the cathode are reduced to deposit solid lead metal, which is the correct answer option B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because: A) Bromine is produced at the anode, not the cathode. C) Oxygen is not produced during the electrolysis of lead bromide. D) Hydrogen is not produced either, as the electrolyte is molten lead bromide, not water.

questions.question_text: The product at the anode during electrolysis of molten NaCl is:
questions.explanation_correct: During the electrolysis of molten sodium chloride (NaCl), the chloride ions (Cl-) migrate to the positive electrode (anode) and undergo oxidation, forming chlorine gas (Cl2) as the product at the anode.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) Sodium (Na) is produced at the cathode, not the anode. B) Hydrogen (H2) is not produced during the electrolysis of molten NaCl. D) Oxygen (O2) is not a product of this electrolysis process, as the anode reaction involves the oxidation of chloride ions.

questions.question_text: In the electrolysis of acidified water, the volume ratio of H2 to O2 is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) 2:1. This is because during the electrolysis of acidified water, the reaction at the cathode is the reduction of water to produce hydrogen gas, while the reaction at the anode is the oxidation of water to produce oxygen gas. The volume ratio of hydrogen to oxygen produced is 2:1, as per the balanced equation for the overall process.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not match the actual volume ratio of the products. The electrolysis of acidified water results in the production of hydrogen and oxygen gases in a 2:1 ratio, as the balanced equation shows. Therefore, the correct answer is C) 2:1, which represents the accurate volume ratio of the two gases produced.

questions.question_text: In the electrolysis of CuSO4 solution using copper electrodes, the anode:
questions.explanation_correct: The mass of the copper anode decreases during the electrolysis of copper sulfate solution because copper from the anode is dissolved and deposited on the cathode, resulting in a decrease in the anode's mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The anode does not increase in mass because copper from the anode is not being added to the solution. Instead, copper from the anode is being dissolved and deposited on the cathode, causing the anode's mass to decrease. The anode also does not remain unchanged or dissolve completely, as the copper is being transferred from the anode to the cathode during the electrolysis process.

questions.question_text: In electroplating, the object to be plated is made the:
questions.explanation_correct: In electroplating, the object to be plated is made the cathode (negative electrode) because the metal ions in the electrolyte solution will deposit onto the cathode, forming a layer of the desired metal on the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The object to be plated is not made the anode (positive electrode) because the anode supplies the metal ions for the plating process, it does not receive the metal deposit. The object also cannot be the electrolyte, which is the conducting solution containing the metal ions. Lastly, the object is not the entire solution, but a part of the setup where the electroplating occurs.

questions.question_text: For silver plating, the electrolyte used is:
questions.explanation_correct: Potassium argentocyanide (KAg(CN)2) is the correct electrolyte used for silver plating because it contains silver ions (Ag+) that can be deposited on the cathode during electrolysis to form a layer of silver metal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not suitable for silver plating. Silver nitrate (AgNO3) and silver chloride (AgCl) are not commonly used as electrolytes for silver plating, and silver sulfate (Ag2SO4) is not an effective electrolyte for this purpose. Potassium argentocyanide is the preferred choice because it provides a stable source of silver ions that can be easily reduced at the cathode to form the desired silver coating.

questions.question_text: Electrolysis is used in the extraction of:
questions.explanation_correct: Electrolysis is used to extract aluminum from its ore, bauxite. This is because aluminum is a very reactive metal and requires a lot of energy to extract it from its ore. The electrolysis process provides this energy, allowing the aluminum to be separated from the other components in the ore.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While electrolysis is used to extract iron, copper, and zinc from their ores, it is not the primary method used for these metals. Electrolysis is most commonly used to extract aluminum, which is a highly reactive metal that requires a significant amount of energy to separate from its ore. The electrolysis process provides this energy, making it the preferred method for producing aluminum.

questions.question_text: Acetic acid is a weak electrolyte because it:
questions.explanation_correct: Acetic acid is a weak electrolyte because it ionizes partially in water, meaning it does not completely break down into ions. This partial ionization is why acetic acid is able to conduct electricity to some extent, but not as well as a strong electrolyte like hydrochloric acid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acetic acid is not a weak electrolyte because it does not ionize completely in water. A weak electrolyte partially ionizes, whereas a strong electrolyte like sodium chloride ionizes completely. Acetic acid partially dissociates into hydrogen and acetate ions when dissolved in water, which allows it to conduct electricity to some degree, but not as strongly as a completely ionized compound.

questions.question_text: The electrode reaction at the cathode during electrolysis is always:
questions.explanation_correct: The electrode reaction at the cathode during electrolysis is always reduction, where positively charged ions gain electrons and are reduced to a lower oxidation state.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Reduction. During electrolysis, the cations (positively charged ions) migrate to the cathode (negative electrode) where they gain electrons and are reduced. Oxidation happens at the anode (positive electrode) where the anions (negatively charged ions) lose electrons and are oxidized. The cathode reaction is always reduction, not oxidation, neutralization, or decomposition.

questions.question_text: When CuSO4 solution is electrolyzed using platinum electrodes, at the anode:
questions.explanation_correct: When CuSO4 solution is electrolyzed using platinum electrodes, oxygen gas is released at the anode. This is because platinum is an inert electrode, and the water in the solution is oxidized to produce oxygen gas at the anode.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because: A) Copper is not deposited at the anode, it is deposited at the cathode; C) Hydrogen is not released at the anode, it is released at the cathode; D) Sulfur is not deposited, the sulfate ion (SO4^2-) remains in the solution. The correct answer is B) Oxygen is released at the anode because the water in the solution is oxidized during electrolysis.

questions.question_text: In the electrolysis of brine (concentrated NaCl solution), the products at cathode, anode, and in solution are respectively:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B. During the electrolysis of brine (concentrated NaCl solution), hydrogen gas is produced at the cathode, chlorine gas is produced at the anode, and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) is formed in the solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because sodium hydroxide (NaOH) is not one of the products. Option C is incorrect because sodium (Na) is not produced at the cathode, and water (H2O) is not the product in the solution. Option D is incorrect because oxygen gas (O2), not chlorine gas, is produced at the anode.

questions.question_text: In electrorefining of copper, impure copper is made the:
questions.explanation_correct: In electrorefining of copper, impure copper is made the anode because the copper in the anode gets oxidized and dissolved into the electrolyte solution, while pure copper gets deposited on the cathode.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that the impure copper is made the anode in copper electrorefining. This is because the impurities in the copper anode get oxidized and dissolve into the electrolyte solution, while the pure copper gets deposited on the cathode. The cathode, electrolyte, and solution are not the correct choices for the impure copper in this process.

questions.question_text: The chlor-alkali process produces:
questions.explanation_correct: The chlor-alkali process involves the electrolysis of sodium chloride (brine) solution, which produces sodium hydroxide (NaOH), hydrogen gas (H2), and chlorine gas (Cl2). This is the correct answer as it accurately describes the products of the chlor-alkali process.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is incorrect because the electrolysis of water produces hydrogen gas (H2) at the cathode and oxygen gas (O2) at the anode, not sodium chloride (NaCl). Option C is incorrect because the chlor-alkali process does not produce oxygen gas (O2) as a product. Option D is incorrect because the chlor-alkali process does not produce elemental sodium (Na) as a product.

questions.question_text: The electrode connected to the positive terminal of the battery is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The electrode connected to the positive terminal of the battery is called the anode. This is because the anode is the electrode where oxidation occurs during electrolysis, and it is connected to the positive terminal of the power source.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cathode is the electrode where reduction occurs during electrolysis, and it is connected to the negative terminal of the power source. The electrolyte is the substance that conducts electricity when molten or dissolved, and an ion is a charged particle, not an electrode.

questions.question_text: Which of the following will NOT conduct electricity?
questions.explanation_correct: Solid NaCl does not conduct electricity because the sodium and chloride ions are locked in a crystalline structure and cannot move freely to carry electric current. Molten NaCl and NaCl solution, on the other hand, have ions that can move and therefore conduct electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options A, B, and D will conduct electricity because the ions in them can move freely to carry the electric current. Molten NaCl and NaCl solution have free-moving ions, while dilute HCl (hydrochloric acid) also has hydrogen and chloride ions that can conduct electricity. Only solid NaCl, with its tightly bound ions, is unable to conduct electricity.

questions.question_text: Dilute H2SO4 is added to water during electrolysis to:
questions.explanation_correct: Dilute H2SO4 is added to water during electrolysis to increase the conductivity of the solution. Sulfuric acid is a strong electrolyte that completely ionizes in water, providing more ions that can carry electric current and facilitate the electrolysis process.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dilute H2SO4 is not added to increase the volume of gases or decrease the temperature during electrolysis. Instead, it is added to increase the conductivity of the solution. Sulfuric acid is a strong electrolyte that completely ionizes in water, providing more ions that can carry electric current and facilitate the electrolysis process. The solution is also not neutralized, as the purpose is to maintain the acidic environment for the electrolysis to occur effectively.

questions.question_text: For nickel plating, the electrolyte used is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Nickel sulphate and ammonium sulphate. This is because nickel plating is done using a solution of nickel salts, and ammonium sulphate is added to improve the quality and adhesion of the nickel coating.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not suitable for nickel plating. Nickel chloride and nickel nitrate are not commonly used for this purpose. Pure water does not contain any ions and cannot conduct electricity, so it cannot be used as an electrolyte for plating.

questions.question_text: Electroplating is done to:
questions.explanation_correct: Electroplating is done to provide a protective and decorative coating on the surface of an object. This is done by passing an electric current through a solution containing dissolved metal ions, which then get deposited on the surface of the object being plated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electroplating is not done to extract metals, purify metals, or decompose compounds. It is specifically used to coat the surface of an object with a thin layer of another metal, which gives it a shiny, protective, and decorative finish. This is achieved by using the process of electrolysis, where the metal ions in the solution are deposited on the object being plated.

questions.question_text: The cathode reaction during electrolysis of dilute H2SO4 is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 4H+ + 4e- -> 2H2. During the electrolysis of dilute sulfuric acid (H2SO4), the hydrogen ions (H+) in the solution are reduced at the cathode to produce hydrogen gas (H2).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect. Option A) describes the anode reaction, not the cathode reaction. Option C) describes the electrolysis of a different compound, sulfate (SO4^2-). Option D) is incorrect because water (H2O) is not directly decomposed at the cathode; instead, the hydrogen ions (H+) are reduced to produce hydrogen gas.

questions.question_text: During electrolysis of molten PbBr2, the anode reaction is:
questions.explanation_correct: The anode reaction during electrolysis of molten PbBr2 is the oxidation of bromide ions (Br-) to form bromine gas (Br2). This is because bromine has a higher reactivity compared to lead, so it is preferentially oxidized at the anode.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the reduction of lead ions (Pb2+) to solid lead (Pb) occurs at the cathode, not the anode. Option C is incorrect because the oxidation of solid lead (Pb) to lead ions (Pb2+) is the opposite of what happens during electrolysis. Option D is incorrect because the reduction of bromine gas (Br2) to bromide ions (Br-) is the reverse of the anode reaction.

questions.question_text: Conduction of electricity through electrolytes occurs by:
questions.explanation_correct: Electricity flows through electrolytes by the movement of ions, not electrons, protons or neutrons. Electrolytes are substances that can conduct electricity when dissolved in water or melted, because they contain ions that can move and carry the electric charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electricity does not flow through electrolytes by the movement of electrons, protons or neutrons. Electrons do not freely move in electrolytes, and protons and neutrons are not the charge carriers. Ions, which are electrically charged particles, are responsible for conducting electricity through electrolytes.

questions.question_text: In electrorefining of copper, pure copper is deposited at the:
questions.explanation_correct: In the electrorefining of copper, pure copper is deposited at the cathode (negative electrode) because during the electrolysis process, copper ions (Cu2+) from the impure copper anode are reduced and deposited as pure copper metal on the cathode.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pure copper is not deposited at the anode, bottom of the container, or surface of the solution. Instead, it is deposited at the cathode, where the copper ions are reduced to form solid copper metal. The cathode is the electrode where reduction takes place during the electrolysis of copper sulfate solution with copper electrodes.

questions.question_text: Aluminium is extracted by electrolysis of:
questions.explanation_correct: Aluminium is extracted by the electrolysis of Al2O3 dissolved in molten cryolite. This is because the melting point of pure Al2O3 is extremely high, so it needs to be dissolved in a molten salt like cryolite to lower the melting point and allow electrolysis to take place.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is the correct answer because aluminium is extracted by the electrolysis of Al2O3 dissolved in molten cryolite, not by electrolysis of aqueous AlCl3 (option A), molten Al2O3 only (option C), or Al2O3 solution in water (option D). The high melting point of pure Al2O3 requires it to be dissolved in a molten salt like cryolite in order to conduct electricity and undergo electrolysis to produce aluminium metal.

questions.question_text: When concentrated NaCl solution is electrolyzed, H2 is produced at the cathode instead of Na because:

options.text: Na is more reactive than H

questions.explanation_correct: During the electrolysis of concentrated NaCl solution, H+ ions are discharged preferentially at the cathode instead of Na+ ions because H+ ions have a lower reduction potential than Na+ ions. This means that H+ ions are more easily reduced to H2 gas than Na+ ions are reduced to metallic sodium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because although sodium is more reactive than hydrogen, this is not the reason why H2 is produced at the cathode instead of Na. Option C is incorrect because sodium can be deposited, but it is not the preferred reaction at the cathode in this case. Option D is incorrect because chlorine gas is produced at the anode, not the cathode, during the electrolysis of concentrated NaCl solution.

questions.question_text: All ionic compounds are electrolytes.
questions.explanation_correct: Not all ionic compounds are electrolytes. For a compound to be an electrolyte, it must be able to conduct electricity when molten or dissolved in water. Some ionic compounds, like table salt (NaCl), are electrolytes, but others like sugar (C12H22O11) are not.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'All ionic compounds are electrolytes' is not correct. Ionic compounds are made up of positively and negatively charged ions, but not all of them can conduct electricity when molten or dissolved in water. For a compound to be an electrolyte, the ions must be free to move and carry electric current. Some ionic compounds, like sugar, do not have this property and are therefore not considered electrolytes.

questions.question_text: Reduction occurs at the anode during electrolysis.
questions.explanation_correct: During electrolysis, reduction occurs at the cathode (negative electrode), where positively charged cations are attracted and gain electrons. The anode (positive electrode) is where oxidation occurs, and negatively charged anions are attracted and lose electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect because reduction occurs at the cathode, not the anode. Cations migrate to the cathode and gain electrons, causing reduction. Anions migrate to the anode and lose electrons, causing oxidation. So the reduction process happens at the cathode, not the anode, during electrolysis.

questions.question_text: Glucose solution does not conduct electricity because glucose is a non-electrolyte.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is true. Glucose is a non-electrolyte, which means it does not ionize or produce charged particles (ions) when dissolved in water. Non-electrolytes like glucose do not conduct electricity because they lack free-moving ions to carry the electric current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Glucose is a non-electrolyte, meaning it does not break down into charged particles (ions) when dissolved in water. Ions are needed to conduct electricity, so a glucose solution cannot carry an electric current. Therefore, the reason glucose solution does not conduct electricity is because glucose is a non-electrolyte, not because it is a strong or weak electrolyte.

questions.question_text: During electrolysis of acidified water, more hydrogen is collected than oxygen.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is true. During the electrolysis of acidified water, the ratio of hydrogen gas produced at the cathode to oxygen gas produced at the anode is 2:1. This is because the overall reaction is the splitting of water molecules, where two water molecules are reduced to produce two hydrogen gas molecules and one oxygen gas molecule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. During the electrolysis of acidified water, the ratio of hydrogen gas produced at the cathode to oxygen gas produced at the anode is 2:1, not more hydrogen than oxygen. This is because the overall reaction is the splitting of water molecules, where two water molecules are reduced to produce two hydrogen gas molecules and one oxygen gas molecule.

questions.question_text: In electroplating, the plating metal is made the anode.
questions.explanation_correct: In electroplating, the metal to be plated is made the cathode (negative electrode) while the plating metal is made the anode (positive electrode). This is because the plating metal needs to be oxidized at the anode to supply the metal ions that get reduced and deposited on the cathode, forming the electroplated layer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect. In electroplating, the metal to be plated is made the cathode (negative electrode) while the plating metal is made the anode (positive electrode). This is because the plating metal needs to be oxidized at the anode to supply the metal ions that get reduced and deposited on the cathode, forming the electroplated layer. The plating metal is not made the anode.

questions.question_text: Anions move towards the positive electrode during electrolysis.
questions.explanation_correct: During electrolysis, anions (negatively charged ions) move towards the positive electrode (anode) to be oxidized, while cations (positively charged ions) move towards the negative electrode (cathode) to be reduced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is a common misconception that anions move towards the positive electrode during electrolysis. However, this is not correct. Anions actually migrate to the positive electrode (anode) where they are oxidized, while cations move to the negative electrode (cathode) where they are reduced.

questions.question_text: In the electrolysis of CuSO4 with copper electrodes, the concentration of CuSO4 remains constant.
questions.explanation_correct: In the electrolysis of CuSO4 with copper electrodes, the concentration of CuSO4 does not remain constant. This is because copper is transferred from the anode to the cathode, causing the copper concentration to decrease at the anode and increase at the cathode.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The concentration of CuSO4 does not remain constant during the electrolysis. As copper is transferred from the anode to the cathode, the copper concentration at the anode decreases, while the copper concentration at the cathode increases. This change in concentration means that the overall concentration of CuSO4 in the solution is not constant.

questions.question_text: Electrorefining is used to purify metals like copper.
questions.explanation_correct: Electrorefining is a type of electrolysis used to purify metals like copper. In this process, impure copper is made the anode and pure copper is made the cathode. When electric current is passed through the electrolytic cell, copper ions from the anode dissolve and are deposited as pure copper on the cathode, leaving behind impurities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrorefining is not used to produce metals from their ores. Instead, it is used to purify impure metals like copper. The impure copper is made the anode and pure copper is made the cathode. When electric current is passed, copper ions from the anode dissolve and get deposited as pure copper on the cathode, leaving behind impurities.

questions.question_text: Weak electrolytes are completely ionized in solution.
questions.explanation_correct: Weak electrolytes are substances that only partially ionize when dissolved in water or other solvents. This means that a portion of the molecules remain undissociated, so they do not completely ionize in solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement that weak electrolytes are completely ionized in solution is false. Weak electrolytes, by definition, only partially ionize when dissolved. This means that some of the molecules remain in their original, undissociated form and do not split into ions. The degree of ionization for weak electrolytes is less than 100%, unlike strong electrolytes which ionize completely.

questions.question_text: Cryolite is used in aluminium extraction to lower the melting point of Al2O3.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is true. Cryolite (Na3AlF6) is used in the electrolytic extraction of aluminium from aluminium oxide (Al2O3) as it helps to lower the melting point of the aluminium oxide, making the electrolysis process more efficient.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Cryolite is added to the electrolytic cell during the extraction of aluminium from aluminium oxide (Al2O3) as it helps to lower the melting point of the aluminium oxide from around 2,000C to around 1,000C, making the electrolysis process more practical and energy-efficient. Without the addition of cryolite, the temperature required for the electrolysis of aluminium oxide would be much higher, making the process more costly and challenging to maintain.

questions.question_text: Substances that conduct electricity in molten or aqueous state are called _______.
questions.explanation_correct: The term 'electrolytes' refers to substances that can conduct electricity when they are in a molten or dissolved state. This is because electrolytes contain charged particles called ions, which can move and carry electric current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'electrolytes'. Substances that can conduct electricity in molten or aqueous (dissolved in water) state are called electrolytes. They contain charged particles called ions that can move and carry the electric current. Other substances that do not conduct electricity in this way are called non-electrolytes.

questions.question_text: The negative electrode in an electrolytic cell is called the _______.
questions.explanation_correct: The negative electrode in an electrolytic cell is called the cathode. This is because during electrolysis, positively charged ions (cations) move towards the cathode and are reduced, while negatively charged ions (anions) move towards the anode and are oxidized.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The negative electrode in an electrolytic cell is not called the anode. The anode is the positive electrode where oxidation occurs during electrolysis. The correct term for the negative electrode is the cathode, where reduction takes place.

questions.question_text: _______ occurs at the anode during electrolysis.
questions.explanation_correct: Oxidation occurs at the anode during electrolysis because the anode is the positive electrode, where the negatively charged ions (anions) are attracted and undergo oxidation reactions to lose electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Oxidation'. During electrolysis, the positively charged ions (cations) migrate to the negative electrode (cathode) where they undergo reduction reactions, while the negatively charged ions (anions) migrate to the positive electrode (anode) where they undergo oxidation reactions. So, oxidation occurs at the anode.

questions.question_text: During electrolysis of acidified water, the ratio of H2 to O2 by volume is _______:1.
questions.explanation_correct: During the electrolysis of acidified water, the balanced chemical reaction shows that 2 molecules of hydrogen gas (H2) are produced at the cathode for every 1 molecule of oxygen gas (O2) produced at the anode. This results in a ratio of 2:1 for the volumes of H2 to O2 gas produced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is a single number, '2', which represents the ratio of 2 parts hydrogen gas to 1 part oxygen gas produced during the electrolysis of acidified water. This is because for every 4 electrons that are transferred, 2 molecules of hydrogen gas and 1 molecule of oxygen gas are formed at the respective electrodes, giving the 2:1 ratio.

questions.question_text: In electroplating, the object to be plated is made the _______.
questions.explanation_correct: In electroplating, the object to be plated is made the cathode because it is the negative electrode where the metal ions from the electrolyte solution get reduced and deposited onto the object, forming the desired plating layer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The object to be plated cannot be the anode because the anode is the positive electrode where oxidation occurs, and the metal from the anode would dissolve into the electrolyte solution instead of being deposited onto the object. The object to be plated must be the cathode, the negative electrode, where the metal ions from the electrolyte get reduced and deposited onto the surface.

questions.question_text: Substances that ionize completely in solution are called _______ electrolytes.
questions.explanation_correct: Substances that ionize completely in solution are called strong electrolytes because they fully break down into ions that can conduct electricity. This is important in electrolysis, as strong electrolytes are needed to provide the necessary ions for the reactions to occur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is 'strong'. Substances that ionize completely in solution are called strong electrolytes, not weak electrolytes. Strong electrolytes fully break down into ions that can conduct electricity, which is crucial for the electrolysis process to occur properly.

questions.question_text: In the electrolysis of molten NaCl, _______ is deposited at the cathode.
questions.explanation_correct: In the electrolysis of molten sodium chloride (NaCl), the sodium (Na+) ions are deposited at the cathode (negative electrode) because they are the cations that get reduced during the electrolysis process.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be chlorine (Cl). During the electrolysis of molten NaCl, the sodium ions (Na+) are attracted to the cathode (negative electrode) and get reduced to form solid sodium metal, not chlorine. The chloride ions (Cl-) are attracted to the anode (positive electrode) and get oxidized to form gaseous chlorine.

questions.question_text: The purification of metals using electrolysis is called _______.
questions.explanation_correct: The purification of metals using electrolysis is called electrorefining. This is because the electrolytic process separates and purifies the desired metal from impurities, resulting in a high-purity metal product.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'electrorefining'. Electrorefining is the process of purifying metals by passing an electric current through a molten or dissolved solution of the metal. This allows the pure metal to be deposited at the cathode, separating it from any impurities.

questions.question_text: During electrolysis, _______ migrate towards the cathode.
questions.explanation_correct: During electrolysis, cations (positively charged ions) migrate towards the cathode (negative electrode) because they are attracted to the negative charge of the cathode. This allows the cations to be reduced and deposited at the cathode.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The question is asking about the species that migrate towards the cathode during electrolysis. The accepted answer is 'cations'. Anions (negatively charged ions) would migrate towards the positive anode, not the cathode, during electrolysis. The cathode is the negative electrode where reduction takes place, so cations are the correct species that move towards it.

questions.question_text: The process of coating a metal object with another metal using electrolysis is called _______.
questions.explanation_correct: The process of coating a metal object with another metal using electrolysis is called electroplating. This is because during electrolysis, the ions of the metal being coated are deposited on the surface of the object, forming a thin layer of that metal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is electroplating. Electroplating is the process of coating a metal object with another metal using electrolysis. This involves passing an electric current through a solution containing the metal ions that will be deposited on the object, resulting in a thin layer of the desired metal coating the surface.

questions.question_text: In the chlor-alkali process, electrolysis of brine produces NaOH, H2, and _______.
questions.explanation_correct: The chlor-alkali process involves the electrolysis of brine (saltwater) to produce sodium hydroxide (NaOH), hydrogen gas (H2), and chlorine gas (Cl2). The chlorine gas is the third product formed during this electrolytic process, along with the sodium hydroxide and hydrogen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is chlorine. During the chlor-alkali process, the electrolysis of brine (saltwater) produces three main products: sodium hydroxide (NaOH), hydrogen gas (H2), and chlorine gas (Cl2). The chlorine gas is an essential part of the chlor-alkali process and is formed at the anode (positive electrode) during the electrolysis.

questions.question_text: In the Hall-Heroult process, aluminium is extracted by electrolysis of Al2O3 dissolved in molten _______.
questions.explanation_correct: The Hall-Heroult process involves the electrolysis of aluminium oxide (Al2O3) dissolved in molten cryolite (Na3AlF6). Cryolite acts as the solvent for the aluminium oxide, allowing it to be decomposed and the aluminium metal to be extracted at the cathode during the electrolysis process.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'cryolite'. In the Hall-Heroult process, aluminium is extracted by the electrolysis of aluminium oxide (Al2O3) dissolved in molten cryolite (Na3AlF6), not in a generic 'molten' substance. Cryolite is a specific compound that acts as the solvent and electrolyte for the aluminium oxide, enabling the extraction of pure aluminium metal at the cathode during the electrolysis.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps of electrolysis in correct order:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: Current passes through electrolyte -> Ions migrate to electrodes -> Ions reach electrodes -> Chemical reaction at electrodes. This is because first the electric current must pass through the electrolyte to create the driving force for the ions to migrate, then the ions move towards the electrodes, and finally the chemical reactions occur at the electrodes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Ions reach electrodes -> Ions migrate to electrodes -> Current passes through electrolyte -> Chemical reaction at electrodes. This is wrong because the ions cannot reach the electrodes before the electric current has passed through the electrolyte to create the driving force for the ions to move. The ions must first migrate to the electrodes after the current has been established in the electrolyte.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps of electroplating in order:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: Object cleaned and made cathode, Prepare electrolyte solution, Pass electric current, Metal ions deposit on cathode. This is because the object needs to be cleaned and made the cathode first, then the electrolyte solution is prepared, and finally the electric current is passed to deposit the metal ions on the cathode.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Metal ions deposit on cathode, Pass electric current, Prepare electrolyte solution, Object cleaned and made cathode. This is wrong because the object needs to be cleaned and made the cathode first, before the electrolyte solution is prepared and the electric current is passed. The metal ions can only deposit on the cathode after all the previous steps have been completed.

questions.question_text: Arrange in order of decreasing conductivity: Strong electrolyte, Weak electrolyte, Non-electrolyte, Pure water
questions.explanation_correct: Strong electrolytes like NaCl have the highest conductivity because they fully ionize in water, producing a large number of freely moving ions that can conduct electricity. Weak electrolytes like acetic acid partially ionize, producing fewer ions, so they have lower conductivity. Pure water and non-electrolytes like sugar do not contain ions, so they have the lowest conductivity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order of decreasing conductivity is: strong electrolyte, weak electrolyte, pure water, non-electrolyte. Strong electrolytes like NaCl fully ionize and have the highest number of freely moving ions, so they conduct electricity the best. Weak electrolytes like acetic acid partially ionize, so they have lower conductivity. Pure water contains some ions from self-ionization, so it has higher conductivity than a non-electrolyte like sugar, which does not contain any ions.

questions.question_text: Arrange the products formed during electrolysis of acidified water in order: At cathode, At anode, Volume ratio (H2:O2)
questions.explanation_correct: During the electrolysis of acidified water, hydrogen gas (H2) is produced at the cathode (negative electrode) through the reduction of water. Oxygen gas (O2) is produced at the anode (positive electrode) through the oxidation of water. The volume ratio of hydrogen to oxygen is 2:1, as for every 2 molecules of hydrogen produced, 1 molecule of oxygen is produced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to list oxygen (O2) at the cathode, hydrogen (H2) at the anode, and a volume ratio that is not 2:1. This is incorrect because during electrolysis, the cations (positively charged ions) are attracted to the cathode and undergo reduction, while the anions (negatively charged ions) are attracted to the anode and undergo oxidation. In the case of acidified water, the cations are hydrogen ions (H+) which are reduced to form hydrogen gas (H2) at the cathode, while the anions are hydroxide ions (OH-) which are oxidized to form oxygen gas (O2) at the anode. The volume ratio of 2:1 for hydrogen to oxygen is due to the balanced chemical reaction that occurs during the electrolysis of water.

questions.question_text: Arrange metals in order of increasing ease of extraction by electrolysis: Fe, Al, Cu, Na
questions.explanation_correct: The order of increasing ease of extraction by electrolysis is Cu, Fe, Al, Na. This is because copper (Cu) is the easiest to extract, followed by iron (Fe), aluminum (Al), and sodium (Na) being the most difficult. The ease of extraction depends on the reactivity of the metal - the more reactive the metal, the harder it is to extract by electrolysis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Cu, Al, Fe, Na. This is not correct because aluminum (Al) is more reactive than iron (Fe), and therefore harder to extract by electrolysis. The correct order is Cu, Fe, Al, Na, with copper being the easiest and sodium being the most difficult to extract by electrolysis.

questions.question_text: How does the cathode differ from the anode in an electrolytic cell with respect to the type of reaction occurring?

options.text: Cathode undergoes oxidation while anode undergoes reduction
Cathode undergoes reduction while anode undergoes oxidation
Both cathode and anode undergo reduction
Both cathode and anode undergo oxidation

questions.explanation_correct: In an electrolytic cell, the cathode is the negative electrode where reduction (gain of electrons) occurs, while the anode is the positive electrode where oxidation (loss of electrons) occurs. Cations are reduced at the cathode and anions are oxidised at the anode.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the reactions: oxidation does not occur at the cathode. Options C and D are incorrect because different reactions occur at each electrode  reduction at the cathode and oxidation at the anode. The mnemonic 'OILRIG' (Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain) helps remember which reaction occurs where.

questions.question_text: How does a strong electrolyte like NaCl differ from a weak electrolyte like CH3COOH in terms of ionisation behaviour in aqueous solution?

options.text: NaCl ionises partially while CH3COOH ionises completely
NaCl ionises completely while CH3COOH ionises partially
Both ionise completely but NaCl produces more ions

questions.explanation_correct: NaCl is a strong electrolyte that dissociates completely into Na+ and Cl- ions in aqueous solution, while CH3COOH (acetic acid) is a weak electrolyte that only partially ionises, producing relatively fewer CH3COO- and H+ ions. This is why NaCl solution conducts electricity much better than an equimolar acetic acid solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the ionisation behaviour. Option C is wrong because CH3COOH does not ionise completely  it establishes an equilibrium between ionised and un-ionised molecules. Option D is incorrect because both substances do ionise in water, only to different extents.

questions.question_text: How does the electrolysis of CuSO4 solution using copper electrodes differ from using platinum electrodes in terms of the product at the anode?

options.text: Copper electrodes release O2 at the anode; platinum electrodes dissolve copper at the anode
Copper electrodes dissolve copper from the anode; platinum electrodes release O2 at the anode
Both produce copper at the anode
Both release O2 at the anode

questions.explanation_correct: When copper electrodes are used, the copper anode itself dissolves (Cu -> Cu2+ + 2e-) and replenishes the Cu2+ ions in solution. When platinum (inert) electrodes are used, the anode cannot dissolve, so water is oxidised instead and oxygen gas is released at the anode (4OH- -> 2H2O + O2 + 4e-).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the two cases. Options C and D incorrectly state both setups produce the same product. The nature of the electrode  reactive (copper) vs inert (platinum)  determines whether the electrode dissolves or whether water is oxidised to release O2.

questions.question_text: How does electroplating differ from electrorefining in terms of the purpose of the process?

options.text: Electroplating extracts metals from ores; electrorefining coats objects with metal
Electroplating coats an object with a thin metal layer for protection; electrorefining purifies an impure metal
Both processes are used to extract metals from their ores
Electroplating purifies metals; electrorefining provides decorative coating

questions.explanation_correct: Electroplating is the process of depositing a thin layer of a desired metal onto an object to provide it a protective or decorative coating. Electrorefining is used to purify an impure metal  the impure metal is the anode and pure metal deposits at the cathode. Though both use electrolysis, their purposes are fundamentally different.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the definitions. Option C is incorrect because neither process is used for extraction from ores  that is a separate electrolytic process. Option D also swaps the definitions. Remember: plating = coating, refining = purifying.

questions.question_text: How does the electrolysis of molten NaCl differ from the electrolysis of concentrated NaCl solution (brine) in terms of the cathode product?

options.text: Molten NaCl produces Na at cathode; brine produces H2 at cathode
Molten NaCl produces H2 at cathode; brine produces Na at cathode
Both produce Na at the cathode
Both produce H2 at the cathode

questions.explanation_correct: In molten NaCl, only Na+ and Cl- ions are present, so Na+ ions are reduced at the cathode to form sodium metal. In brine (aqueous NaCl), both Na+ and H+ ions are present; since H+ ions are preferentially discharged (being lower in the electrochemical series), hydrogen gas is liberated at the cathode instead of sodium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B reverses the products. Option C is wrong because sodium is not deposited from aqueous solution  H+ ions are discharged preferentially. Option D is wrong because in the absence of water (molten state), there are no H+ ions, so sodium metal is formed.

questions.question_text: A substance dissolves in water and the resulting solution conducts electricity very poorly, with only a small fraction of its molecules forming ions. This substance is best classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: A substance that dissolves in water and partially ionises  with only a small fraction of molecules forming ions  is classified as a weak electrolyte. Examples include acetic acid (CH3COOH) and ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH). The solution conducts electricity poorly because there are fewer free ions compared to a strong electrolyte.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because a strong electrolyte ionises completely, not partially. Option C is wrong because a non-electrolyte does not produce any ions at all. Option D is incorrect because metallic conductors carry current via free electrons, not ions in solution.

questions.question_text: An electrode in an electrolytic cell attracts negatively charged ions, and these ions lose electrons at its surface. This electrode is best identified as the:
questions.explanation_correct: The electrode that attracts anions (negatively charged ions) must be positively charged, which identifies it as the anode. At the anode, anions lose electrons (oxidation). For example, during electrolysis of molten PbBr2, Br- ions migrate to the anode and are oxidised: 2Br- -> Br2 + 2e-.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A and C describe the cathode, which is the negative electrode that attracts cations (not anions). Option D incorrectly pairs the anode with reduction  the anode is always the site of oxidation in an electrolytic cell.

questions.question_text: In an electrolysis experiment, an ionic compound is heated until it melts and then electrolysed. A shiny metal deposits at one electrode and a coloured gas with a pungent smell is released at the other. The electrolyte is most likely:

options.text: Molten NaCl, producing sodium and chlorine
Acidified water, producing hydrogen and oxygen

questions.explanation_correct: The description matches molten NaCl: sodium metal (shiny) deposits at the cathode and chlorine gas (greenish-yellow, pungent smell) is released at the anode. Acidified water produces colourless, odourless H2 and O2. CuSO4 with Cu electrodes transfers copper without any gas. Al2O3 produces aluminium and O2 (colourless).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is wrong because both hydrogen and oxygen are colourless and odourless gases. Option C involves a solution, not a molten compound, and produces no pungent gas. Option D produces colourless oxygen, not a coloured pungent gas. Only chlorine fits the description of a coloured gas with pungent smell.

questions.question_text: A factory uses electrolysis to deposit a thin layer of chromium onto steel bumpers to prevent corrosion and improve appearance. This industrial application is best classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Depositing a thin layer of one metal (chromium) onto another object (steel bumper) using electrolysis for protection and decoration is the definition of electroplating. The steel bumper is made the cathode, chromium is the anode, and a chromium salt solution acts as the electrolyte.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (electrorefining) is about purifying an impure metal, not coating an object. Option B (electrolytic extraction) is about obtaining a metal from its ore. Option D (chlor-alkali process) produces NaOH, Cl2, and H2 from brine, which is unrelated to metal coating.

questions.question_text: Riya sets up an electrolysis experiment in her school laboratory using acidified water with platinum electrodes. After running the experiment for 20 minutes, she observes gas collecting in both the inverted test tubes placed over the electrodes. She notices that the test tube over one electrode has collected twice the volume of gas compared to the other. Which gas has the larger volume and at which electrode is it collected?

options.text: Oxygen at the anode has the larger volume
Hydrogen at the cathode has the larger volume
Hydrogen at the anode has the larger volume
Oxygen at the cathode has the larger volume

questions.explanation_correct: During electrolysis of acidified water, hydrogen gas is produced at the cathode and oxygen gas at the anode in the volume ratio 2:1. Since Riya observes one tube has double the volume, that tube contains hydrogen collected at the cathode. The equation is: 2H2O -> 2H2 + O2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because oxygen is the gas with the smaller volume (half of hydrogen). Option C incorrectly places hydrogen at the anode  hydrogen is produced at the cathode by reduction of H+ ions. Option D incorrectly places oxygen at the cathode  oxygen is formed at the anode by oxidation of OH- ions.

questions.question_text: During a visit to an electroplating factory in Pune, Amit observes a worker dipping iron spoons into a solution and connecting them to a battery along with a nickel bar. The worker tells Amit that after a few hours the iron spoons will have a shiny nickel coating. In this setup, what role does the iron spoon play?

options.text: It is the anode because it supplies metal ions
It is the cathode because the nickel coating deposits on it
It is the anode because it gains electrons

questions.explanation_correct: In electroplating, the object to be coated (iron spoon) is always made the cathode (connected to the negative terminal of the battery). Ni2+ ions from the electrolyte solution are reduced at the cathode surface and deposit as a thin layer of nickel metal on the spoon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because the nickel bar is the anode that dissolves to supply Ni2+ ions, not the spoon. Option C is incorrect because the electrolyte is the nickel salt solution, not the spoon. Option D wrongly identifies the spoon as the anode  the anode loses electrons (oxidation), it does not gain them.

questions.question_text: Priya is performing a conductivity experiment in her chemistry practical. She tests four solutions  sodium hydroxide, acetic acid, glucose, and dilute sulphuric acid  by connecting each to a circuit with a bulb. She finds that the bulb glows brightly for three solutions but does not glow for one. Which solution causes the bulb to NOT glow?
questions.explanation_correct: Glucose is a non-electrolyte  it dissolves in water but does not ionise into ions. Without free ions, the glucose solution cannot conduct electricity and the bulb will not glow. NaOH, CH3COOH (though dim for weak electrolyte), and dilute H2SO4 all produce ions and conduct electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because NaOH is a strong electrolyte that fully ionises. Option B is incorrect because acetic acid, though a weak electrolyte, still partially ionises and can conduct some current. Option D is wrong because dilute H2SO4 is a strong electrolyte. Only glucose produces no ions at all.

questions.question_text: Arjun heats lead bromide in a crucible until it melts and then passes electric current through it using carbon electrodes. He observes a silvery grey substance forming at one electrode and reddish-brown fumes rising from the other electrode. At which electrode does the silvery grey substance form, and what is it?

options.text: At the anode; it is bromine
At the cathode; it is lead
At the anode; it is lead
At the cathode; it is bromine

questions.explanation_correct: During electrolysis of molten PbBr2, Pb2+ ions migrate to the cathode and are reduced to form silvery grey lead metal (Pb2+ + 2e- -> Pb). The reddish-brown fumes at the anode are bromine vapour produced by oxidation of Br- ions (2Br- -> Br2 + 2e-).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because bromine is reddish-brown fumes, not a silvery grey substance. Option C incorrectly places lead at the anode  the metal cation always deposits at the cathode. Option D wrongly identifies bromine at the cathode  bromine is an anion product formed at the anode.

questions.question_text: Meera reads in her textbook that aluminium is extracted by the Hall-Heroult process. She learns that Al2O3 has a very high melting point of about 2072 degrees Celsius, which makes direct electrolysis impractical. A substance is added to reduce the melting point to about 950 degrees Celsius. What substance is added, and why is it necessary?

options.text: Dilute H2SO4 is added to increase conductivity of the solution
Cryolite (Na3AlF6) is added to lower the melting point of Al2O3
NaCl is added to provide Na+ ions for the reaction
CaCO3 is added to act as a flux and remove impurities

questions.explanation_correct: Cryolite (Na3AlF6) is mixed with Al2O3 to lower the melting point from about 2072 degrees Celsius to approximately 950 degrees Celsius. This makes the electrolysis economically feasible by drastically reducing the energy required to maintain the molten state.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the process involves molten (not aqueous) electrolysis and H2SO4 is not used. Option C is wrong because NaCl is not added in the Hall-Heroult process. Option D is incorrect because CaCO3 is a flux used in blast furnace iron extraction, not in aluminium extraction.

questions.question_text: Which of the following appears to be an electrolyte based on its ionic formula but does NOT conduct electricity in its normal solid state?
questions.explanation_correct: Solid NaCl is composed of Na+ and Cl- ions, so students often assume it should conduct electricity. However, in the solid state the ions are locked in a rigid crystal lattice and cannot move freely, so solid NaCl does NOT conduct electricity. It only becomes a conductor when molten or dissolved in water, where ions are free to move.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options B, C, and D all conduct electricity because their ions are free to move. Molten NaCl has mobile ions due to melting, dissolved NaCl has ions dispersed in water, and dilute HCl has H+ and Cl- ions in solution. The exception is solid NaCl, where ions exist but cannot move.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is commonly mistaken for an electrolyte but is actually a non-electrolyte?
questions.explanation_correct: Alcohol (ethanol, C2H5OH) is a liquid that dissolves in water and contains hydrogen and an -OH group, which misleads many students into thinking it will ionise like acids or bases. However, alcohol is a covalent compound that does not ionise in water, making it a non-electrolyte.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (HCl) is a strong electrolyte that fully ionises in water. Option C (CH3COOH) is a weak electrolyte that partially ionises. Option D (NaOH) is a strong electrolyte. The exception is alcohol, which despite having an -OH group and being a liquid, does not produce ions in water.

questions.question_text: During electrolysis of aqueous CuSO4 using platinum electrodes, which of the following does NOT occur?

options.text: Oxygen is released at the anode
The blue colour of the solution gradually fades
The concentration of CuSO4 remains constant throughout

questions.explanation_correct: With inert platinum electrodes, Cu2+ ions are removed from solution and deposited at the cathode, but no copper dissolves from the anode to replace them. Therefore, the concentration of CuSO4 decreases over time and the blue colour fades. The statement that concentration remains constant is the one that does NOT occur  this only happens when active copper electrodes are used.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and C all correctly describe what happens. Cu2+ ions deposit as copper at the cathode. OH- ions are oxidised at the platinum anode releasing O2. As Cu2+ ions are consumed, the blue colour (due to Cu2+) fades. Only option D is false  concentration decreases with inert electrodes.

questions.question_text: Why do cations migrate towards the cathode during electrolysis?

options.text: Because the cathode is positively charged and attracts cations
Because the cathode is negatively charged and attracts the positively charged cations by electrostatic force
Because cations are heavier and sink to the bottom where the cathode is placed
Because cations are pushed away from the anode by other anions

questions.explanation_correct: Cations are positively charged ions. The cathode is connected to the negative terminal of the battery and carries a negative charge. Opposite charges attract each other due to electrostatic force, so cations migrate towards the negatively charged cathode where they gain electrons and are reduced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because the cathode is negatively charged, not positively charged. Option C is a misconception  ion migration is driven by electrostatic attraction, not gravity. Option D is wrong because cation movement is due to attraction towards the cathode, not repulsion from anions.

questions.question_text: Why is dilute sulphuric acid added to water before carrying out its electrolysis?

options.text: Because H2SO4 reacts with water to produce hydrogen and oxygen directly
Because pure water is a very poor conductor of electricity and the acid provides free H+ and SO4^2- ions to increase conductivity
Because H2SO4 lowers the boiling point of water so electrolysis occurs faster
Because the acid is needed to dissolve the platinum electrodes

questions.explanation_correct: Pure water is an extremely weak electrolyte with very few H+ and OH- ions, making it a poor conductor. Adding dilute H2SO4 introduces a large number of H+ and SO4^2- ions, dramatically increasing the conductivity of the solution. The SO4^2- ions remain in solution (not discharged), while H+ and OH- from water are selectively discharged to produce H2 and O2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because H2SO4 does not directly react with water to produce gases  the gases are produced by electrolysis at the electrodes. Option C is incorrect as H2SO4 does not lower the boiling point significantly. Option D is false because platinum is an inert metal resistant to acid attack.

questions.question_text: Why is the impure copper block made the anode (and not the cathode) during electrorefining of copper?

options.text: Because the anode is where reduction occurs, so impurities get reduced and removed
Because at the anode, oxidation causes the impure copper to dissolve as Cu2+ ions, leaving behind insoluble impurities as anode mud
Because the anode is lighter and impure copper is heavy
Because the impure copper needs to attract anions to become pure

questions.explanation_correct: At the anode, oxidation occurs: Cu -> Cu2+ + 2e-. The impure copper anode dissolves, sending Cu2+ ions into the CuSO4 electrolyte. Insoluble impurities (like gold, silver, platinum) do not dissolve and settle as 'anode mud' beneath the anode. The Cu2+ ions then migrate to the cathode where they are reduced and deposited as pure copper.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A wrongly states the anode is the site of reduction  oxidation occurs at the anode. Option C is irrelevant; electrode placement has nothing to do with weight. Option D is incorrect because the purpose is not to attract anions but to dissolve the impure copper through oxidation so that pure copper can be redeposited at the cathode.
